awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Selective Oxidation Catalysis on Oxides Containing Pores of Molecular Dimensions
awd_abstract_narration:
Our modern standard of living depends upon the fuels that are needed for our transportation, and the chemicals that are used to make many of the materials of our many consumer products. These fuels and chemicals are predominantly derived from the conversion of fossil fuels into value-added chemicals and materials via catalytic reactions. Thus, the environmental footprint of our lifestyles can be significantly reduced with more efficient use and conversion of these raw materials. One example of a catalytic upgrading reaction is the conversion of shale gas to bulk chemical and fuel precursors.  Conversion of the short, saturated hydrocarbon molecules (light alkanes) within shale gas to alkenes leads to a more reactive, and thus more valuable, chemical intermediate.  This conversion involves the removal of hydrogen atoms and insertion of a more reactive carbon-carbon double bond.  To perform this conversion at low temperatures requires use of a catalyst, and one such example is a mixed metal oxide catalyst. The objective of this project is to understand how the size and shape of pores within the mixed metal oxide may be engineered to more selectivity catalyze the oxidative alkane to alkene reaction.
 
This project will probe the role of micropores in ordered bulk transition metal oxide catalysts in the selective hydrocarbon oxidation of small alkanes and alkanols. Ordered M1 phase mixed oxides contain one dimensional pores that are similar in size to the kinetic diameters of the reactants; examples include M1 phase mixed oxides of Mo V, Te and Nb and octahedral molecular sieves of Mn oxides. The project will correlate the oxidation rate ratios of linear versus branched alkanes to cycloalkanes to pore dimension, with consideration of pore sizes that exhibit size exclusivity. Kinetic and density functional theory (DFT) will probe selectivity with variations in pore geometry, reactant geometry, and surface reactivity. It is anticipated van der Walls stabilizations and steric hindrance may limit conversion to secondary byproducts, which may enhance selectivity by bypassing the thermodynamic driving forces for secondary oxidation reactions to secondary byproducts. Planned education and outreach activities will promote understanding of heterogeneous catalysis and its role in meeting the challenges of sustainable chemical production and energy efficiency. These activities will target students from underprivileged backgrounds, with an aim to increase their retention in science and engineering fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Overview.

Intellectual Merit.

Our research concerns the selective oxidative dehydrogenation of hydrocarbons. A comparison of molybdenum and vanadium based oxides with octahedral molecular sieves (OMS) in terms of shape selectivity has been extensively studied. Ethane and cyclohexane activation rates were nearly insensitive to low vanadium loadings on silica. M1 phase MoVTeNb and MoV mixed oxides contain one-dimensional micropores of size similar to ethane but much smaller than cyclohexane. Preparation methods significantly affect their elemental composition, accessible micropore volumes and surface areas. Post-synthesis treatment of MoVTeNbO with hydrogen peroxide improves M1 phase purity, and increases in hydrocarbon activation rates are consistent with increases in their intrapore and external surface areas. Image 1 shows molecular sizes and accessibility to lattice oxygens in pores of M1 phase and on outer surfaces of oxides.1

Propane and propene oxidations on the M1 phase exhibit relatively high selectivity to acrolein and acrylic acid. We probed the ability of the reactant molecules to access the catalytic sites inside the pores of these oxides and analyzed elementary steps that limit selectivity. Measured propane/cyclohexane activation rate ratios on MoVTeNbO are nearly an order of magnitude higher than non-microporous vanadia silica, which suggests significant contribution of M1 phase pores to propane activation because both molecules react via homologous rate-limiting C−H activation. Density functional theory suggests that desired propane dehydrogenation and propene allylic oxidation to acrolein and acrylic acid are limited by C−H activation steps. Calculated activation barriers for C−O formation are invariably higher than C−H activation when these activations occur inside the pores, suggesting that reactions restricted within the pores are highly selective to desired products.2

OMS materials have also been extensively studied for their wide array of catalytic applications. These materials are classified by their different tunnel sizes defined by edge-sharing MnO6 octahedra. Four different OMS materials (OMS-1, OMS-2, OMS-5, and OMS-6) were benchmarked for ethane and cyclohexane oxidative dehyrdrogenation (ODH). The role of the quadrilateral tunnels of the OMS materials was further evaluated using density functional theory (DFT) for C2H6 and cyclohexane (C6H12) to estimate accesibility of these molecules to the micropores.OMS showed ODH rates were much higher than those measured for the M1 phase. In addition, M1 phase MoVTeNbO, commercial MnO2, and V2O5 were also tested for comparision.  C2H6 and C6H12 ODH rates for OMS materials were much higher than those measured for M1 phase MoVTeNbO, commercial MnO2, and V2O5. Product selectivities for C2H6 and C6H12 suggest that OMS materials proceed towards the higher oxidation product (CO2) rather than ethylene or benzene, respectively.3

     Solid state magic angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (MASNMR) of the vanadium OMS systems as well as high resolution aberration corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy studies have been developed. MASNMR studies to obtaine crystallograpic data and distinguish various size pores have been done. Studies of this type have not been done in the past and have revealed interesting data concerning OMS materials with variable pore sizes. Analytical studies in the microscope were done with electron energy loss spectroscopy to investigate effects of pore sizes and defects. These vanadium based studies are unique and give detailed structural and compostional information.4 

Broader Impacts.

     The broader impacts of this work involve dissemination of knowledge regarding effects of pore sizes in catalysis. These studies are relvant to research in the areas of catalysis, materials science, synthesis, charaterization, and computational modeling. Development of new state of the art characterization studies were done that are relevant to all the above mentioned resaerch areas. Education of undergraduate and graduate students in these areas has been done in terms of development of research skills, mentoring, and enhanced communication skills such as reports, oral presentations, team meetings, and writing of papers. In addition, posters and oral presentations of this work have been given in local, regional, and national meetings. Joint meetings with our collaborators at Tufts University were done in person as well as virtually during the whole project.  

References.

1. Annamalai, L.; Ezenwa, S.; Dang, Y.; Tan, H.; Suib, S. L.; Deshlahra, P., Comparison of Strutural and Catalytic Properties of Monometallic V and Mo Oxides and M1 Phase Mixed Oxides for Oxidative Dehydrogenation, Cat. Today, 2021, 368, 28-45. 

2. Liu, Y.; Twombly, A.; Dang, Y.; Mirich, A.; Suib, S. L.; Deshlahra, P., Roles of Enhancement of C-H Activation and Diminution of C-O Formation within M1-Phase Pores in Propane Selective Oxidation, ChemCatChem, 2021, 13, 784-899. Cover Feature. 

3. Khanna, H. S.; Dang, Y.; Twombly, A.; Mirich, A.; Shirazi-Amin,A.; Perera, I.; Liu, Y.; Deshlahra, P.; Suib, S. L., Assessment of Micropore Accessibility for Hydrocarbon Oxidation in Manganese Oxide Sieves, 2021, in preparation. 

4. Mirich, A.; Eddy, N.; Tan, H.; Suib, S. L., Characterization of Vanadium based Octahedral Molecular Sieves using Magic Angle Spinning Nuclear Magnetic Resonance, Electron Paramagnetic Resonance, and Aberration Corrected Scanning Traansmission Electron Microscopy Methods.  

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 09/06/2021
Modified by: Steven L Suib
